citeinfo.origin: Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council, James Bodkin of the U.S. Geological Survey, Anchorage, Alaska and Thomas A. Dean of Coastal Resources Associates, Inc., Carlsbad, California.
citeinfo.title: The Western Gulf of Alaska - A Summary of Available Knowledge

descript.abstract:
This book references population abundance and species composition data of invertebrate communities in western Gulf of Alaska,
The aforementioned data are referenced in citation: AEIDC and Institute of Social, Economic and Government Research. 1974. The Western Gulf of Alaska - A summary of available knowledge. Prepared under contract to Marine Minerals Division, BLM, Washington. University of Alaska, Anchorage, 599 pp.
This literature was collected as part of a metadatabase that represents one or more nearshore resources (from physical attributes such as water and air, to birds and mammals). Each entry is viewable in three formats, 1) a geospatial explicit format (ArcView 3.3) named GIS ArcView 3.3 Near GEM project, 2) a spreadsheet format (Excel 2002 and within ArcView) named GEM Nearshore Metadata Set, and 3) a ProCite database named GEM Nearshore Metadata References, which consists of references included in 1 and 2 above. The ProCite database record number corresponds to the Excel Procite Number. Reference Procite #5 for this literature's metadata.
The metadata are maintained in digital format (ArcView 3.3, Excel 2002, and Procite) and are available from the Alaska Science Center, USGS in Anchorage, Alaska.
For a detailed description of the three databases and the project, see "Bodkin, J. L., and T. Dean. 2003. Alternative Sampling Designs for Nearshore Monitoring (Gulf Ecosystem Monitoring and Research Project G-030687), US Geological Survey, Alaska Science Center, Anchorage, Alaska." available on-line at http://www.evostc.state.ak.us/pdf/GEM_final_reports/030687.pdf.
descript.purpose: Part of the GEM Nearshore Metadata References database, which is a reference collection of studies of a select assemblage of marine taxa, including alga, invertebrates, fishes, birds, and mammals that occupy nearshore habitats of the Gulf of Alaska.

distinfo.distliab: While every effort has been made to ensure that these data are accurate and reliable within the limits of the current state of the art, NOAA cannot assume liability for any damages caused by any errors or omissions in the data, nor as a result of the failure of the data to function on a particular system.
